Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract

Organic semiconductors are carbon-based materials, similar to dyes, that conduct electricity. They can be dissolved in solvents and printed using inkjet-printing on flexible substrates for use in low-cost electronics such as displays and sensors. Light emitting diodes based on organic semiconductors are already commercially available in mobile phones. With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, this research project expands their use through the study of their fundamental physical properties such as their electrical conductivity, and explores possibilities for converting excess thermal energy to electrical power. The project has significant impact on the future scientific workforce because graduate student researchers carrying out the research gain significant training in multidisciplinary materials science and engineering. The research team also performs outreach to the public through educational activities in local K-12 schools.


Technical Abstract

A key challenge in molecular organic electronic materials is the control of their electronic properties through solid state ordering. Electrical doping of organic semiconductors is important for electrode layers in organic light emitting diodes and solar cells and in emerging thermoelectric applications. The research in this project examines how the crystalline order in solution processed organic semiconductors, both in neat films and in blends with acceptors, affects their electrical conductivity and electronic structure. The intrinsic properties of electrical conduction are compared in samples doped by molecular acceptors in model bilayer structures and in the bulk. Thermopower measurements and advanced x-ray structural characterization are carried out to determine how the microstructure and electronic structure of organic molecular solids evolve upon electrical doping. Gated thermopower measurements are used to determine the electronic structure of undoped materials to gain insight into their electronic structure. This research provides insight into new means to control the electrical conductivity of organic semiconductors in order to determine the limits of the electrical properties of these important materials systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic, i.e. carbon-based, semiconductors are an important class of materials for thin film electronics.  These materials can be coated into thin films from solvents using simple printing methods and are currently used in displays as light emitting diodes (LEDs). This project examined the thermoelectric properties of molecular and polymeric organic semiconductors. Thermoelectric materials can convert a difference in temperature into an electrical voltage and can be used in devices that convert waste heat into electricity.  The performance of organic semiconductors as thermoelectrics depends on the ability to control the number of electrical charge carriers in the material.  The concentration of charge carriers is controlled by molecular dopants that alter the microstructure of materials relative to their insulating form. During the project, changes in the microstructure of organic semiconductors during electrical doping were investigated using advanced X-ray scattering methods as well as electrical transport measurements. The thermoelectric properties of amorphous molecular semiconductors were studied using a new method of electrical doping that lead to efficient charge generation and uniform morphologies. The role of the connectivity of crystalline and amorphous domains on the thermoelectric properties of polymeric semiconductors were elucidated. These studies revealed the interplay between order and disorder on the electrical properties of organic semiconductors.

 

The broader impacts of the project include research of materials for pressing societal needs and the training of the next generation STEM workforce. There is a societal need to develop methods to efficiently manufacture electronics that can be readily integrated into systems for sensor webs or wearable electronics.  The materials studied in the project can be used for energy scavenging from the environment addressing the need for self-powered systems reducing the reliance on batteries. Graduate students in materials science carried out the research gaining experience in developing new materials and advanced analytical methods.  The project also introduced a diverse group of undergraduate researchers to research in materials science.  The participants in the project were engaged in public outreach events in local K-12 schools.
